benchmark_details.name: GRAPE (Grouped Ranking-Aware Policy Optimization Enhancement)
benchmark_details.overview: GRAPE is a plug-and-play enhancement approach that incorporates ranking signals into retrieval-guided query rewriting with LLMs to improve retrieval performance under distributional shifts including multilingual, length, and modality differences.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To enhance CLIP-based retrieval systems under distributional shifts without costly re-embedding or redeployment.

data.source: Five representative benchmarks including Flickr30k-CN, CVLUE, XM3600, Wikipedia, and CIRR.
data.size: 148,915 training queries, 29,783 training images for Flickr30k-CN; similar sizes for others.

methodology.calculation: Ranking rewards are computed based on the relative ranking of the target image against generated queries.
methodology.interpretation: Higher Recall@1 and Recall@10 indicate better retrieval performance.
methodology.baseline_results: Improvements of 4.9% in Recall@10 over CLIP with LLM rewriting.
methodology.validation: Conducted on training and validation splits of each benchmark dataset.
